38586647.review: I can't suggest this game enough. Imagine Oregon Trail mixed with the zombie appocalypse and you have this game. A genuinely fun, challenging experience where you can put you and your friends in as characters and see how long you last. Making it to Canada is one of the most fun things I can say I've done in a game. Another nice element is that this isn't a serious game by any means. It's goofy, with random encounters with aliens, ridiculous death messages, and all in all a comedic aspect to it. Overall, if you have a few dollars to spare, this game is a must buy. This game will run like a gem on any computer, and is overall one of the best games I think I've bought on steam.

38586161.review:
A very fun arcade-style survival adventure in which you take control of up to 4 party members and attempt to cross country to Canada whilst killing zombies, avoiding bandits, and other unfortunate events. This game is deceptively charming and very cute: pop culture references and hilarious dialogue boxes make up the bulk of that. 

Gameplay is fun too, you can choose to either melee hordes until you run out of stamina and get eaten alive, or you can play smart and outmaneuver the one in a small room by pushing furniture against the door. You also have to manage gasoline, food, medicine and ammo. Honestly the game feels roughly difficult to The Binding of Isaac, but I haven’t played too long at the time of this review. There’s a bulk of unlockables to achieve through a single play through by grabbing ZOMBPOINTS (or some shit like that) and upgrading existing traits and perks. Oh, I forgot to mention, there’s character customization too! Very fun if you want to recruit your family and friends later in game and then laugh your head (or scream your head) off when they get killed in action. 

All in all, I give this game an 8/10. Give it a try, steam sale is still goin on!

38404884.review:
A top-notch random generation survival game, Death Road to Canada has several things going in its favor. It's kind of like Oregon Trail meets FTL meets Gauntlet, with an amazing sense of humor as you guide your team from Florida to Canada. While the zombies are your most frequent enemy, what really makes the game is the variety of weapons, hilarious random encounters (telling a pack of ambushing bandits to "COOL IT!" can have wildly unpredictable results), and a custom character creator that allows reasonable copies of almost anyone you can think of. 

I bought this game close to launch, and the developer just keeps engaging with the community and adding fun new things. It's easily worth full price and then some. The latest updates brought me back for another run and I'm enjoying it tremendously!

Or to put it in a much shorter way: If "Dead Rising merged with FTL merged with custom character creation and an amazingly devoted developer sounds fun to you, get this."

38385513.review: The ultimate road trip simulator has finally arrived, and boy is it a doozy. Taking pages from games such as Oregon Trail, FTL, and many more, Death Road is a fantastic blend of gameplay, humor, and substance rolled into one giant fun burrito. Crafting your motley crew of idiots, you hop in a car and speed off in the direction of the Great White North, the last bastion of humanity against the zombie menace. Along the way you'll learn new things, meet annoying people, splatter a lot of zombies, amass more weapons than a rogue state, and ultimately die horribly three days from the Canadian Border because your cat went ballistic on you. Behind the goofy exterior lies a challenging, but entertaining game--those having a hard time with the basic gamemode can try Rare Characters mode, a magical place where special characters might join you on the road to Canada. Not enough time for the long haul? Short Trip to Heck gives you a fraction of the time you have in the base game, promising more risk, but maybe better rewards! The game itself looks and sounds decent enough--you'll quickly get bored of the soundtrack and replace it with something better, but the characters and the dialogue will leave you giggling for at least a little while. Death Road, as the name suggests, is not a forgiving mistress--RNG can make or break your run in a matter of seconds, and one broken down car or angry pal can spell doom.The biggest offender, in my opinion, is the gaping hole of usefulness between melee and ranged weaponry. Even if you build your character(s) to be car-chucking ubermen, your trip will come to an abrupt end more often than if you focused more on firearms. Add the nebulous skill/trait system into the mix (Max Rank in Mechanics? Too bad--have fun repairing anything until halfway through the run) and you have a game that is fun when it works, but frustrating when it throws you a curveball. That being said, if you hedge your bets by training hard and keeping your characters happy, you'll be eating poutine in no time at all. All in all a fun game to play on a coffee break or a lazy Sunday. Bring a friend!

38291614.review:
Can't recommend this game enough, seriously, everything that Death Road to Canada has to offer is fantastic. Even for casual gamers, Death Road starts off so simple that even your grandma could play it. That is, until she reaches the halfway point to Canada in which things start to become a little more stressful as zombies become more aggressive and materials such as food, gas, and ammo began to disappear faster than you can gather it. Not to mention all of those random events which can be tremendously overpowering (at the time),  or absolutely devastating. You can never truly be prepared or have too much stuff in this game thanks to these events. Also, the character customization is fun but could use some more tools. I do love that there is the "play with familiar characters" option, as surviving the zombie apocalypse along side my AI controlled friends is a good time. The only gripes I have with this game are; 1. Giving the AI controlled characters a gun is a horrible idea as they tend to not know how to conserve ammo at all, and 2. There isn't online multiplayer, which I think would be a terrific addition to the game, even if it’s only with one other player. That's all though, everything else about the game is superb. 

10/10 would play as a shotgun-wielding dog again.

38253241.review:
[b]TL;DR[/b]
> I’m alone.
> I reach a wooden bridge walled off by bandits.
> They demand everything I own.
> I threaten to burn down the bridge.
> They let me pass, unscathed.
> I pass.
> I burn the bridge as I go.

[h1]FULL REVIEW[/h1]
An actual in-game event I had the pleasure of witnessing. And if that hasn’t sold you on Death Road to Canada, then damn, I don’t know what will. Won the game as a paranoid ex-surgeon with a crappy attitude who robbed and double-crossed everyone he met – what about that is not the best thing you’ve ever heard? But okay, if you’re still wondering what exactly the game has to offer, that’s what this review will get into. Because I am obsessed with this game.

Death Road to Canada is a zombie survival game that messes with just about every trope in others of the genre. It's more of an arcade-style game – somewhere between an RPG and a rogue-like -- where you collect loot and team mates to accompany you on a progressively hard journey to the not-destroyed haven of Canada. With simple gameplay of guns and melee weapons, it doesn’t sound too unique. But what sets this game apart is the content and tone.

[b]SELLING POINTS[/b]
To start with, it has ridiculous replayability. Different modes to try out with varying difficulties, a long-ass list of rare characters to run into, and dozens of perks and traits to assign to your own custom characters. Add to that some rare traders with rare weapons, rare events that give you better (or worse) loot, vehicles, etc. I’ve played quite a bit, and I still have so much to get through. And even if you know what you [i]can[/i] run into, there’s still the excitement of wondering what you [i]will[/i] encounter each game. Hoo-boy.

What surprised me most of all, though, is that Death Road to Canada offers you so many choices. Not just for combat, but as text events. These events often come up with dialogue-style options that determine what your group gets/loses from them. Depending on which characters you have, and their stats, you can respond differently. The choices are what really separates this from similar games, as there are a countless number of them, and they end up giving your characters personality and charm every round (and sick loot, of course).

If I had to compare it to another game, I would say The Binding of Isaac. Both loot-based games with procedurally-generated scenarios, simple gameplay that gets harder as you continue, and tongue-in-cheek humour. The main difference is that The Binding of Isaac is almost impossible to play in the later stages without either an otherworldly memory or help from the wiki for item synergies, whereas Death Road to Canada encourages you to play the game time and time again, testing things out for yourself being part of the journey. There are so many things to find, while at the same time, there isn’t too much for it to feel overwhelming.

As with other loot-based games, there’s a pretty heavy element of RNG in this one. That would usually be an issue, but I think Death Road to Canada balances it well with skill and risk-and-reward mechanics, so it rarely seems unfair. Couple that with some pleasant visuals and sweet chiptunes, and you’ve got yourself a good game that I’ll be playing for ages.

[b]OVERALL RATING[/b]
The most fun I’ve had in a while, with some of the best humour and gameplay to lose yourself in for a few hours, and enough to keep you coming back. Might seem a bit gruelling at first, but give it a shot! If I have any complaint at all it’s that the combat itself might feel a little repetitive once you get a good strategy sorted out, as most weapons essentially work the same way.

Oh, and how is the American hero Tommy Wiseau not a character in this game? Come on, he’s perfect for it. Last words when getting gnawed by zombies: “YOU’RE TEARING ME APART!”

(He could also have the ‘Friend of Dog’ bonus, it’s truly meant to be.)

9/10

Bought it because it looked like Organ Trail, but i was very shocked when i played it.
Turns out this game is WAY better.

PROS:
- Custom characters, special characters, random characters, many characters. I have done 10 runs to Canada (and i still haven't made it, difficult as fuck), alterned between normal and rare (special) characters mode, haven't got a single character who looks or acts the same yet. Because of this and the (apparently) procedurally generated maps, every playtrough seems fresh. You'll play hours and hours and the game will still feel fresh.
- As mentioned before, the game IS hard and you'll constantly fail, but it's charming in a way you'll only get more interested in your next save every time you lose.
- Haven't run into a single bug yet. Bugs begone.
- Every single minimal detail of the game seems to have received special attention. The Dev team has polished EVERY. SINGLE. SPOT of this game.
- The graphics, zombies, characters and general, are very charming.
- Has many different mechanics and still being updated with new ones, 1 year after the release.
- During your gameplay, you'll make WAY more choices and feel way more in control of the game than you would in Organ Trail (drawing a comparison)
Cons:
- I don't really fucking know any. This is how good this game is.

Overall, 10 out of FUCKING 10, definitely one of the best games of the genre on steam, in my opinion.
Also, if you read this, don't ever recruit Garfielf if you want to live. You can thank me later.

38027788.review:
DEATH ROAD TO CANADA这款游戏中文全称为“前往加拿大的死亡之路”，所以顾名思义，就是个想尽一切办法苟活十几天撑到加拿大的游戏。原谅我不太清楚各类游戏的具体划分标准，所以我会尽我所能向你描述一下这个游戏。
以前玩过盗版，入正之后稍微玩了下（因为也没太多时间玩游戏），发现有些内容可以说与1年前的版本完全不同。
1.我在进入游戏后应该干啥？
首先，进游戏后可以选择一个我也不知道是不是叫做商店的地方。在那里可以用点数换取一系列我也忘了是什么的升级。对，向那些NPC对话一下就行了。无奈很多升级意思也不太懂，我用我拙劣的幼儿园英语水平连带猜发现部分升级是有利有弊的，以及似乎得到点数的方法是浏览作者推特等网站（似乎仅一次）以及在日常游戏中探索获得。

2.然后呢？
好，然后在进游戏之前我们最好创建2个自定义人物。1个也没问题，甚至不搞也没什么问题。可以选择一些人物特质，比如说擅长近战，枪械，修车，医疗等等技能。不过技能一般有利也有弊。同时还可以选性格，等等等等就不再多加叙述了，反正我玩的也不是太久这些不太清楚。

3.我是不是应该进游戏了？
是，是的，你进游戏就会有辆车。开始游戏之前可以看一些游戏提示。大部分人物属性是隐藏的，必须进行过有关行为才能发现人物属性。从哭脸到笑脸代表弱到强。

4.我开着车然后干啥？
一般开车的时候会有一些突发事件，这里举几个例子：（大部分靠猜）
有人放屁
僵尸堵路
洪水来了
有人心情不好想踹个人下车（包括他自己）
遭遇火灾
遭遇陷阱镇
有个人挡着你不让你过
遇到熟人
等等等等的事件，不一一概述了，反正我也忘得差不多了。
从中我们可以发现的是，有部分可以用来搜刮的事件（就是给你下车自由活动的）拿来几选一，这说明了什么？说明作者不过是想定期检验一下你的属性如何罢了。

5.就一直这么开下去？
那，大部分事件还是要求你下车打架的。不可能打人的，这辈子都不可能打人的，打的是路上的丧尸。需要注意的是，每个事件都有特定时间，然后晚上丧尸更快更强环境也更黑暗。这意味着你可能晚上收刮就得怂的下了车就上车溜之大吉，不过这也不失为智举，反正能活就行。

6.武器是咋回事？
另外，开局每人有配带手电和随机近战武器1个。手电大部分时间是晚上逃跑用的，不能与近战武器和枪支共同使用，也没有把手电绑在枪上这种设定，因为本身手电就是核能手电永远会亮的，再这么搞的话黑暗就显得没太多氛围了。另外千万别用手电打怪，会碎的...
说起这个，就要讲一下武器栏的事情。每个正常人标配3武器栏，特殊人物视情况而定。回到车上可以把武器放车上，不过也有栏位限制。另外还有燃烧弹手榴弹等投掷类武器，也占一个武器位。
武器损坏不是视耐久度而定，而是有一个固定的几率损坏。

7.我的人物打了一会就累的流泪了怎么办啊？
另外人物打久了会累然后流汗，这时候打怪就跟用羽毛打一样轻。所以当面对一大波怪的时候要不拿起你的霰弹枪或者燃烧瓶，要不就靠你的走位开溜。不过有时候会让你在一个地方守几小时，特别坑。

8.我的车怎么一直在掉螺丝钉啊？
一般车开久了就会烂。除了找汽修店以及汽修工队友靠玄学修好车一般车烂了就下车步行了。

9.所以，我要走路去加拿大？
没了车以后会有很多负面事件以及极少的正面事件。举一些例子吧：                                                                                            
看到石头以为是车，难受然后降低心情                                          
石头勾脚，难受然后降低心情
被强盗日常收保护费，降低心情和丢物品或者打架全员受伤
下雨，日常降低心情
等等等等。
然后是必然事件：找到车。穿过丧尸堆然后找到车（必定可以开）然后上路。
生活就是车坏了→找车→车又坏了→又找车....

10.我撑到加拿大边境了，但这怪是怎么回事啊？？
呃，这个。如果没有神队友，神武器，神移速的话就躺在地上等死算了吧。


以上，一个刚玩这游戏的萌新的十分不全面的评测。必然有一大堆与事实不符的情况或者描述不恰当的语句，以及十分丑陋令人捉急的排版。
还请大家指出错误，不胜感激。







最后什么时候实现多国语言化和线上多人联机的承诺？恳求官方帮助我们这些不擅长英文的人更好地融入游戏气氛，而不会因为看不到内容而大伤脑筋。

We need more languages so that we can enjoy this game easier.Please!

텍스트 기반 인카운터와 픽셀 액션을 합친 기발한 게임입니다.

좀비사태로부터 안전한 캐나다로 향하는 15일간의 여정에 관한 게임이며,
반복되는 인카운터 나 전투 도중 확률적으로 나타나는 특별한 이벤트가
게임을 반복하게 만드는 중독성을 유발합니다.

게임에서 가장 중요한 부분은 자원관리 입니다.
식량과 기름, 의약품이 중요한 건 게임을 접해보면 바로 알 수 있지만,
총알의 중요성은 후반으로 갈수록 더더욱 중요합니다.
국경을 가기전 마지막 4시간의 혈투라거나,
국경에서의 수많은 좀비떼들을 상대해야 하기 때문입니다.

전투 같은 경우에도 스테미너의 관리가 매우 중요합니다.
아무리 강한 캐릭터 강한 동료들이 있어도 스테미너가 떨어지면 공격속도가 현저히 줄어들게 됩니다.
좀비의 공격을 받아도 공격속도가 줄어들기 때문에,
자리 선정 뿐만 아니라 스테미너 관리가 전투의 핵심이라고 볼 수 있습니다.

즉, 15일간 단순히 캐릭터를 생존시키기만 할 것이 아니라,
캐릭터의 능력치를 개발시키는 것은 물론,
총알을 미리미리 비축하여 거대한 좀비떼에 대비하여야 합니다.

실력과 경험을 바탕으로 행운을 필요로 하는 정말 적절한 로그라이크 좀비 게임이라고 생각합니다.

37940683.review:
Death Road to Canada is set in the zombie apocalypse. America has been completely overrun, and the player has to drive and fight their way north, to the safety of Canada.

You need to search buildings for food, fuel for your car, medical supplies, weapons (melee and guns) and ammo. You’ll also encounter scenarios, for example bandit attacks, or hazards blocking the road, and your choices can result in positive or negative consequences. Each character in your group has a range of stats including strength, shooting, medical, mechanical and morale, which can be either increased or decreased. You could also gain or lose supplies, or take damage.

You’ll start with either one or two characters, and along the way you’ll meet new people who you can recruit, up to a maximum party size of four. You directly control one character, but you can switch at any time. Party members can die permanently, but as long as you’ve still got one person alive, the journey can continue.

The best part of the game is the special characters who can be recruited. My favourite so far is Valkyrie, who is pretty much a female version of Marvel’s Thor, equipped with Mjolnir and capable of smashing through zombies in melee and at range. I’ve also met a professional boxer who has killer punches, a medieval knight, and a sumo wrestler.

You can create custom characters, but this isn't as fun as it sounds, because you're almost forced to play characters with good fitness and strength skills. Anyone else will get tired quickly when attacking repeatedly, which means melee attacks get slower and do less damage, resulting in a much lower chance of surviving “sieges”, which is when your group is attacked by a massive horde of zombies. Most of the time, there’s no way to avoid a siege, you just have to survive it.

The core gameplay loop is enjoyable, but my main problem with DR2C is that its really short. A successful run only takes around 90 minutes, and I survived all the way to Canada on my second attempt. After that all you can really do is roll a new character and go again. Sure, you'll encounter some different scenarios and meet new characters, but you'll also quickly start to see repeats. There are some different gamemodes (shorter journey, extended journey, special characters only, hard mode) but they don’t really vary the gameplay at all. In less than 6 hours I’ve beaten 3 gamemodes, and I’m already feeling a lack of motivation to continue. Having said that, purchase price is cheap so its easy to get value for money.

Oooh boy, this game. 
This game has to be one of the most entertaining, yet frustrating games I've ever played. 
Why, you ask?

Well...
1st day - I start off, immediately gaining tons and tons of supplies. I, of course, am stoked. Tyler (leader) and Bianca (buddy) meet a car mechanic named Steven. He doesn't seem very special.
2nd day - Still going pretty well, discovering everyone's morality, skills and such.
3rd day - I kick Steven the mechanic out as soon as we meet another survivor, Dom. He doesn't even have good mechanical skills, and we already have his nice car.
4th day - Aaaand our car has broken down. I'm starting to regret kicking Steven out. Dom attempts to fix it by raging and punching it. He breaks the car even more, AND breaks his hand. Struggling here.
5th day - I find another survivor, Dolly. Dom nearly dies three times; twice in a siege, one in a raid.
6th day -  Bianca is attacked by a feral cat, causing her  health to plummet. We are THEN attacked by a swarm of ants right after that. That's not all, folks! Dolly doesn't notice a hole in her backpack. We lose a crapton of supplies. 
7th day - supressing rage as car breaks down
8th day - oh hey another car- oh nevermind it broke as soon as we got in. Dom punches it again, becomes hurt. Again. 
9th day - Everyone dies in a siege -_-

All in all, I'm glad I received this as an early Christmas gift. I can't get enough of playing it, even if I've only played it for an hour!

37887768.review:
I really want to like this game but despite throwing a ton of interesting mechanics together, it's just not "fun". I think this stems from a common problem in procedurally generated games which is that things feel random and without meaning. Primarily:
- The random events that occur on the road have huge consequences on your group but you have almost no agency over them.  They just happen to you. 
- The precedurally generated towns provide lots of random rooms and alleys with no meaning or consequence. Some levels would benefit from a human designer to create intrigue.

At the end of the day it gets pretty tedius to be thrown into a loop of randomized towns and randomized events.

37860630.review:
It's Oregon Trail meets River CIty Ransom with zombies, which, I mean, the Oregon Trail Zombie thing was done and kind of sucked, BUT!
There are a variety of extremely familiar but legally non-actionable characters to collect!
You can recruit dogs to your team, and they can be taught to shoot guns!
You can recruit three dogs in a trenchcoat to your team!
You can solve the mystery of who farted in the car!
You can be laid low by the CURSE OF ANIME!
You can defeat bandits by showing off your supreme swoleness!
You can experience the terror of a box with a small amount of poo on it!
You can get kicked out of every establishment in the post apocalyptic wasteland by telling people to COOL IT and SAY IT DON'T SPRAY IT!
You can build any variety of dingus, jerk, or miscellaneous in the character creator!
There are so many unexpected and hilarious things that can happen in this game, and the game itself is straightforward and enjoyable, but can also go extremely sideways based on your decisions. 

In the action sequences, there's only one enemy type - zombies, with various appearances and temperments, but they all move like the classic Romero slow zombie.  The action is very brawler-like, but your characters are extremely limited by their stamina - after a few swings, more if you have more stamina, you start getting red and sweaty, you swing slower and hit for less damage. If a zombie grabs you, you move more slowly, act more slowly, and need to get out of its grasp quickly or you'll start taking damage. It starts out pretty managable, with scattered oblivious zombies that won't even notice you unless you go out of your way to disturb them, but eventually you're fighting clusters of hundreds of zombies at a time, all actively hunting you. You will learn why slow zombies ain't a joke. 

Trying to avoid getting too winded while dealing with an ocean of zombies, wave after wave gradually filling in every empty space on the map - it's then that you bring out the firearms. But ammo is very limited, and you'd better have some saved up for the grand finale, so you're weighing the risk of continuing to just bash the zombies versus pulling out your guns and easily managing the horde, but wasting valuable ammo.

Of course, you could get robbed by bandits, or you could run out of food and have one of the ungrateful dinguses steal all your resources and run away.

There is a lot of luck involved - I doubt every game you start is winnable, sometimes you just hit a streak of miserable luck. This might turn a lot of people off, for good reason - but in a way, that's the game's charm. More than a survival game, it's a road trip game, and when you pack a bunch of people into a shitty old car and drive across the country, there's no way you can account for everything that will happen along the way.  There's less chance of your friends being eaten during a road trip, of course, but you know what I mean. The game's goofy sense of humour softens its capricious and often malicious edge.

As well, as a Canadian, this game has the most accurate portrayal of our fine country since Super Punch Out's Bear Hugger.

37815417.review:
So, Oregon Trail but with zombies, a create-a-character, gobs of traits you can assign to said characters, playable "looting" sections where you smash and shoot up hordes, the soundtrack breaking out into chiptunes ragtime music now and then, and one of the most wacky, cheerful apocalypses you'll see in a game.

You'll fail and fail again, continuing to throw your min-maxes custom characters, complete randoms, dogs who can drive, and the occasional "special guest character" into the grinde. You'll be dying to things ranging from the boring old zombie bites, to trying and failing to wrestle a moose, to telling a wizard to COOL IT.  You'll curse yourself as your strategy falls apart because you can't help but pick the comedy option, and your character gets himself killed trying to retrieve a can of baked beans.  You'll feel the pathos of having to make the decision to let a chicken run free, or be "nuggified" for a half a day's rations.

Even if the simplistic, pixel art style or the "oh boy yet another zombie game" turns you off, it's a very solid game with loads of replayability, gobs of things to try and see, and a pretty darn solid soundtrack.  (No online co-op tho, which may be a deal breaker for some, just on principle.)

1.好玩，这是一个策略生存的轻度rougelike游戏，整个游戏分成两部分，搜刮和应急处理。搜刮阶段主要是和僵尸战斗以及搜索补给，补给包括食物，药品，汽油，子弹(手枪/步枪，机枪，霰弹三种)，武器。战斗将会损失武器的耐久，而每名角色最多只能携带三把武器，进而使得后期玩家在遇见尸潮时团灭。整个团队最多只要四个单位，每个单位拥有个自的职业和专长，在后期还能学习各种技能。由于开始只能选择你自己和你的跟班，所以最终你的团队是怎么样也很难说。搜刮阶段还包括交易，营救，生存，逃生等次要目标，如何在降低损失的同时增加搜刮获得的补给是一个很有意思命题。而应急处理阶段则是处理各种突发事件，比如遭遇劫车，突发受伤/生病/熄火，安排搜刮地点，有人想入队等。如果团队中有角色拥有对应这项事件的技能，则会增加处理这件事情的方法的选项，同时降低玩家的损失。
2.游戏的彩蛋异常多
3.现在30不到的价格真的很划算(入过包就另说了)

Great Oregon-Trail type of game! Honestly was supprised how much I enjoyed this game, going into it with little to no prior knowledge. 
Just for reference: I have played (and beaten) every game mode, and experienced most of the random events

PROS:
-Outstanding re-playability
-RNG is pretty fair and balanced (compared to other games of this type)
-Humorous approach to an often serious topic
-Familiar characters make it a bit more personal
-soundtrack
-Local 2-player works well enough

CONS:
-AI is usually reliable, but sometimes it makes silly mistakes (or drops your rare weapons for golf clubs)
-RNG can screw you over at times
-Some events seem to appear very often, which makes some runs a bit more bland
-Marathon mode (help me)
-No steam cloud (could be added later?)
-No online multiplayer (could be added later?)


ALL AROUND: 8/10
Highly recommended, especially if you have some friends to play with. (I put 40+ hours into this game in my first week, it's a bit addictive). So if you like Oregon trail type games, or zombie games in general, grab this and give it a try!

37534301.review:
DR2C is an awesome game to play either by yourself or with a friend. The game features a fun character creator in which you can make all your friends with unique appearance and personality. I find the core gameplay tense and fun, as every character play and act differently, and you need to plan out every move and choice carefully to secure a successful run. The humor is top-notch. I often find myself laughing at the random scenarios I encounter on my way to Canada. DR2C offers a lot of replayability due to its wide selection of game modes and varied characters.

I only have a few cons about the game. It would have benefitted from a more convenient way of quitting in the middle of a run without clearing the save file. The only way I've figured out to do this is pressing Alt+F4 (it's not a joke, it actually works). Another thing is I wish DR2C had online co-op. The devs have said that this is a feature they want to implement, but lack experience with developing online multiplayer games. It's not that big of a deal, but would have been awesome.

You should get this game if you like mechanics like beat 'em up combat, resource management, fatal choices, character customization and local co-op. The developers frequently release new patches with new content and general improvements.

37476892.review:
All right, the premise is basically:
[olist]
[*] Take Oregon Trail
[*] Toss in top-down Zelda-styled exploration and combat
[*] Add the co-op zombie fighting with a variety of weapons from Left 4 Dead
[*] Mix things up with procedurally generated story choices reminiscent of Faster Than Light
[/olist]

It's already a winning concept, but Death Road to Canada ties it all together with a [i]fantastic[/i] sense of humor and satisfying gameplay. It's difficult enough to require focus and timing, and difficult enough that your choices have weight to them, without the game being unfairly hard. The randomization elements also keep there from being one "correct" way to play the game; while one playthrough is relatively short (just as was Oregon Trail), subsequent runs are constantly throwing you into new situations, and there's a variety of different modes to replay the game in as well as unlockables, a character creator, and local multiplayer to keep things fresh.

The music is enjoyable, though there's not many tracks and the game would benefit from having more variety in that regard (especially since other aspects of the game tend to be better at avoiding repetition). The zombies are often [i]visually different[/i], which is a nice touch, but where Left 4 Dead adds Special Infected with unique abilities into its assortment of undead, Death Road to Canada doesn't capitalize on the opportunity to do something similar. Outside of these minor gripes, the complete package is thoroughly entertaining.

Death Road to Canada has something to offer for a wide variety of players, and it's a gem that's definitely worth giving a try.

37459489.review:
This is my first review ever written, but boy does this game deserve it.

Death Road to Canada is a charming game about surviving a trip to Canada through swarms of the undead. If you don't like apocalyptic games, try DR2C. I never cared for them, but this game definitely switched my views. I personally haven't gotten to Canada yet, but I always come back to it since the possibilities in-game are endless. No two games are exactly alike, making each time you replay it a brand new adventure. It can be challenging using a keyboard though, so I definitely recommend a controller to make the gameplay more fun and smooth. 

Another charming thing about this game is that you can customize your own characters. Create yourself, your sibling, your mom, your dad, your great grandmother, your favorite Youtuber, legitimately anyone. There are multiple different traits and perks to give them, which give you advantages and disadvantages when you begin the game/someone joins your team. You can level up perks, and even unlock new ones as you earn points by playing the game. 

The one thing that can be iffy at times is leveling up a character's basic skills in game. To know how good/bad they are, you have to go through an event to reveal said skill, or it will be randomly revealed. If you do not know how the character is at the skill, it'll be a mystery when you level them up. This doesn't hinder the gameplay, but it may get on some people's nerves just a bit. 

In conclusion, Death Road to Canada is a charming, fun game that will have you coming back for more. (Even after you brave the Road and make it to Canada.)

37366949.review:
J'ai d'abord été sceptique sur ce jeu est voulu voir ce qu'il vallait avant de l'acheter. Mais maintenant que je le possède, je ne regrette pas du totu mon achat. Même si le style Pixel fait un peu mal au yeux et peu déranger certaines personnes, le jeu en lui même est une petite perle dans les jeu de son style. Un humour sympa dans une invasion zombie post-apocalyptique pas du tout pris au sérieux. Chaque aventure sera différente! Point bonus de ma part pour la possibilité de pouvoir te créer toi ou tes proches avec un mode réservé pour eux, Vancaces entres potes au millieu d'une amérique zombifiée ! Quelques point négatif tout de même sont : Entres les missions de récoltes, le peu d'interactions entre les personnages fait souffrir un peu le gameplay du jeu, Il est très facile de tomber sur les mêmes évenements ou dialogue dans la même partie. L'autre point négatif serait au niveau de la collecte de resources, là, le jeu ne vous fait pas de cadeau et est très inéquilibré au niveau des ressources possibles d'obtenir dans une mission de récolte. Vous perdrez souvent à cause d'un manque d'une ressource particulière. 
Malgré tous, ce jeu reste quant mêmeun jeu exelent pour ce qu'il est. Il y a pas mal de débloquable et de succès à avoir ce qui pourrais vous prendre une petite trentaine d'heures si vous y mettez bien.^^ Jeu très bien, mais à acheter en solde.

36644012.review:
Death Road to Canada ist ein perfektes Spiel für einen gemütlichen Koop Abend zu zweit.
Es geht darum, der Zombie-Apokalypse zu entkommen und nach Kanada zu reisen. Dabei passieren unvorhergesehene Events und Vorfälle, bei denen wichtige Entscheidungen getroffen werden müssen. Das Spiel nimmt sich auch gerne selbst auf die Schippe und die Situationen reichen von ernsthaften Überlebensentscheidungen zu teilweise wirklich lächerlich witzigen Vorkommnissen. Jeder Spieldurchlauf fühlt sich anders an und man hat eigentlich immer etwas zu lachen.

Während man nach Kanada reist, muss man Zwischenstopps einlegen um Nahrung, Benzin, Munition usw. zu sammeln. Dabei wird das Game zu einer Art Top-Down Hack&Slay im Stil von Hero Siege. Die Zombiehorden sind reichlich platziert und oft muss man abwägen, ob es nicht besser ist die Beine in die Hand zu nehmen oder man doch noch dieses eine Haus versucht zu looten. Unterwegs trifft man auf kuriose Charaktere, Händler, Banditen und verrückte Tiere :D
Man kann für seine Survival-Gruppe bis zu 3 zusätzliche Personen rekrutieren.

Leider hab ich es bisher nicht bis nach Kanada geschafft denn das ist eine größere Herausforderung als vorher gedacht :D Dennoch habe ich mit dem Spiel schon mega viel Spaß gehabt und ich bin mir sicher eines Tages das Ziel zu erreichen.

Wer sich vom minimalistischen Stil des Spiels nicht abschrecken lässt sollte sich Death Road to Canada zumindest mal ansehen. In den 2h in den man ein Game refunden kann, hat man mehr als genug Zeit sich einen Eindruck davon zu machen was dieser Titel zu bieten hat.

*Englischkenntnisse vorausgesetzt*

Viel Spaß :)

36609563.review:
Amazing game

My first winning run was on normal mode but my main character died leaving me with a random girl. Along the way she met Jason from friday the 13th, Link from legend of zelda, and an Elvis impersonator (again I stress that this was not a rare characters run). Jason possessed an unbreakable machete. Link wielded a magical sword that could shoot magic missiles. Finally, Elvis wielded an angels voice that could win the heart of a tyrant and also constantly attracted zombies to our party during raids.

Random girl, Jason, Link, and Elvis had many adventures from the time they almost died in a shopping mall to because the security guards kept blocking the door to that time Jason summoned spirits on a ouija board. Alas, nothing gold can stay. In the last 3 days of the journey, a series of travesties befell the party. Elvis fell like many elvis's before him, to blockages caused by human excrement. Seriously though, he died in a sewer right at the border of canada. Rando girl, Link, and Jason wiped their tears and soldiered onwards knowing that a such a voice was to be forever lost to Canada and the world.

The party came to a Cabin in the woods to reflect and regain their energy but found they had been followed from the sewers by a herd of zombies. On this scenic cabin by the lake, the trio fought for their lives. Here, Jason too fell like many before him: slashing up bodies while trespassing on a campground. Except this Jason's slashing was for the love of his friends, not the hate of his enemies. Link dumped his body in the lake because he knew Jason would want that. Rando Girl picked up Jason's indestructible and swore she would live to tell Canada of Jason's redemption.

Finally, almost at the border of Canada, Link and Rando girl were trapped while passing through a city. Rando girl's skill with Jason's infamous machete complemented Link's finesse with the sword of evil's bane. Despite the fact that their party was smaller than ever, they found the strength to fight like an army. The copious amount of submachine gun ammo helped as well. However, predictable as it may be, Link was not destined to leave this city alive. As he lay dying on the ground in Rando girls arms, he gave her his sword and said something to the extent of "You will be endangered if you travel by yourself, have this".

Rando girl ran as fast as she could and found herself at the gates of Canada itself. Months of travelling had put her within a stone throw away from canada but tens of thousands of zombies at the iron walls of Canada blocked her way. Machete in one hand, master sword in the other, she set at them. Her comrades didn't die for nothing. Even though the ammo was all gone, her chainsaw still had gas and she was all out of bubble gum. The border guards didn't see her walking to the gates until she was in spitting range, only a cloud of blood that seemed to drift through the horde towards them. Of course, such a warrior was welcomed into Canada.

I would like to think that Rando girl never met these three characters. They were her way of coping with the harshness of the death road after my main character died.

36598795.review:
Where do I even start with this game.

Do I make this review fun, original or nice to read?
I should, because that would be completely in the spirit of the game.

Alright, so imagine the apocalypse. 
The stereotypical one. With zombies, survivors, bandits and all that jam.
You're thrown in a car with some dork of your choice (or alone, if you swing that way) with nothing but a bit of food, some gas and two flashlights.
You have one goal, one destiny.

- Canada -

The last safe haven of America.

Got that picture in your head? Nice.

NOW THROW IT OUT THE WINDOW, BECAUSE THIS GAME IS JUST COMPLETE MADNESS.

So, true, you start in a pretty standard vehicle and try to find your way to said country.
But, oh boy, the ride couldnt be any wilder, even if it's name was Gene.

Much like a chocolate factory, this game is filled to the brim with joy, humor and sweet remarks about the pop culture we're living in.
You can encounter an exploding Anime Girl, Gordon Freeman, Jason, Garfield, Men in Black, Santa Claus, Knights, Cavemen, Skeleton Queens, Rick Grimes, Link and like a hundred more of special characters.
All of them are playable.
All of them have different abilities.
All of them can be a big pain in the bum or your last hope of making it to the paradise of maple syrup.

If you think you're a creative fella, well then make your own survivor with his or her own special abilities! (But some of them are only useable after you unlock them with zombo points, which you gain during the game, so.... this game even has an upgrade-system - pretty swell, right?)

And much like the original adaptation of "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory", this game is also filled with brutality and death.
The difficulty level varies with the gamemode you're playing and did I say "Gamemode"? Indeed, I did!
Wether you like the normal experience, only like to encounter your own made characters or only rare, special ones; if you like to have a short ride or a long one or just want to torture yourself, this game can deliver.
So it goes from somewhat challenging to "Sweet embrace of death, please end this eternal suffering".

"But what after I made it to Canada? WHAT THEN, BAMJAM?", I hear you all asking.
First of all, good luck getting all the achievements, meeting all the special characters and beating all the gamemodes.
After you did all of that... Well, what do I know. I'm not at that point yet.
You're probably gonna fall in an abyss of pure depression, because this game is just that outstanding.

Did I mention that this game has no loading times, doesnt need internet and can run on a toaster?
Now I did.
 
Gameplaywise it's like a mix of top-down hack-and-slay scavenging missions, micromanagement - much like "Oregon Trail" and a textbound CYOA.

Really, there's something for everyone.
I'd say that it's worth the full price.
What are you waiting for?
Get your sweet cheeks to Canada.

This game is simply amazing, and is well worth the 15 dollars. Everything is accurate, from how often you need food to how much gas you would need. If you still don't want to buy this game, here's something that's happened to me in-game .

Everything was going well. Then my friend died, and I recruited a dog named Woof to the party. We came across bandits, and I made my character distract them while Woof got away. Apparently my character was untrustworthy and joined the bandits, turning on Woof and injuring him in the process. Soon after Woof (now the only person left in the part) had his morale at rock bottom, and said that someone in the party wasn't pulling their own weight. The only option was Woof, so, sadly, I had to make Woof kick himself out. Woof left in anger, and the dream of making it to Canada was dead.

12/10 Would recommend to anyone who likes zombie survival games or games similar to the Oregon Trail. Would have myself betray a dog again.

36545251.review:
I bought Death Road To Canada due to one of my friends telling me how much he loved it. This was recently after I bought Organ Trail, so the zombie road trip “genre” or whatever had actually become a significant part of my gaming life for some time. As such, I will make multiple comparisons between the two games during this review, though I think I can make a decent case for this game even if you haven’t played Organ Trail.

Now, I’m not about to crap on Organ Trail here; it’s a fun game and appeals well to nostalgia. However, in terms of sheer fun I’ve had from both games, DR2C FAR  exceeds Organ Trail. I believe this is because DR2C naturally has a lot more player input when compared to Organ Trail. During your time on the Death Road, you’ll make many choices that can have serious ramifications for your characters. If you make the wrong decision, it could cost you valuable supplies, your car, or even a party member’s life. Believe me,  in that final stretch of the game, you’ll need as many people as possible.

Characters are handled  much better in this game as well.  Unlike in Organ Trail, where your characters are mere sprites that are essentially interchangeable, your party members in DR2C will stand out from one another, not just in appearance, but in ability. Every character has a perk, an advantage to help them survive the Death Road, and a trait, which gives them a personality quirk. This applies to both your random and custom characters. Considering how you can only start with 2 characters, but can have a party of four, the people you  pick up along the way can complement each other’s skills or lead to bitter infighting.  As weird as I may sound, I frequently get emotionally attachedto my ragtag crews, and the adventure often feels like it has actual weight to it.

Not that Death Road to Canada is all doom and gloom. The game handles the apocalypse with a cheeky sense of humor and no small amount of pop culture absurdity. Find a naked horse man running about? You can recruit him! A dog joins the party? Teach it how to shoot a shotgun!  Run into a man selling anime and anime accessories? Buy a figurine from him to raise morale! The dead walking the Earth is far from being the strangest thing happening here.

Lastly, the game is significantly more difficult to survive to the end in normal mode than Organ Trail was on its hardest difficulty, and I think it’s better because of it. The zombies in DR2C don’t infect you when they bite, but 3 bites without healing is enough to kill most characters, and you can kiss one goodbye if he/she gets swallowed up by a horde. Combine this with a  15 day journey ending in a massive final challenge means that you’ll probably TPK more often than have anyone make it to Canada. Yet I’d argue the journey beats the destination in this case.  Even when you fail, the game’s dynamic keeps you entertained, and you’ll always have an absurd, entertaining story to watch anyway.

In conclusion, Death Road to Canada is definitely worth the price  from my perspective. It styles itself in a way that gives it a ton of replay value, sprinkles in addicting gameplay, and mixes it all together with a lovable and strange cast of characters (both your own and the rares). I would definitely recommend.

36450965.review:
I'm glad I waited until I had one successful trip under my belt before writing this, Death Road can vary wildly in difficulty due to it's randomly generated nature. It can feel brutally unfair at times; characters can get tired quickly and be unable to fight back, which in siege events can mean certain, cheap feeling death. However, overall the game is very compelling and charming. Each attempt feels like the start of a new story, helped by random events and characters appearing. You learn to cut and run when appropriate, which weapons suit you best, and when it's worth taking a risk. You really get into the spirit of it all, and feel like you're just scraping by most of the time. 

The game has a good sense of humour, and had me laughing fairly often. It's light hearted, not grimdark, which helps the whole permadeath thing not sting as much as it could have. If you go into Death Road to Canada anticipating fun little vignette stories that will probably end badly, it's a blast. If you set out to win, you're going to be disappointed. I couldn't say how heavily the randomisation factors is, I haven't played it enough to accurately say, but it *feels* like you're destined to crash and burn at least a dozen times before you make it.

tl;dr fun little roguelite, randomisation can mean life or death, very charming and endearing, great to play over lunch or just for an hour when you need a break from other stuff. Definitely recommend if you're into these kinds of games!

36302645.review:
I've been following this game for well over a year before I finally decided to pick it up. This was easily one of the best games I've purchased on steam.

The premise is pretty simple, You start with 1-2 characters and your ultimate goal is to survive for fifteen days until you can make it to Canada. All characters have random stats, A personality trait, And a skill that can benefit one of or more of their stats. The catch for the most part is that you have no idea as to what these stats actually are. Traits can also cause positive effects, However they can also enduce consequences. A large part of the game is simply trying to figure out what it is each person is good at, And developing a balanced skillset between your party members.

However it's not always that easy. While trying to learn as much about your chracters as you can, You also need to stock resources for your team. Ultimately when you fail to do this, Party members can end up dead or abandon your party all together. You are able to recruit newer members to replace fallen ones, However it starts the education process all over again. Sometimes you may even encounter special characters who can do unique things.

This is a great game all around, If nothing else you should easily be able to get 20~ hours out of it. Which for a sixteen dollar game is a pretty fair pricepoint.

簡単にガイドも書いたのでぜひ遊んで欲しい作品。
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1183493642

FTLとかのローグライクなゲームが好きな人ならハマれると思う。
安息の地「カナダ」を目指してゾンビアポカリプスの世界を車で旅します。

キャラクターはランダムで作るのも良し、自分で好みのキャラを作るも良し。
基本二人をキャラメイクorランダムで選んで2人旅で始まりますが、相棒オフにすると1人で開始になります。
道中ではイベントやマップで仲間を増やせることも。最大４人で旅をしよう。

1. 車での移動（ランダムでイベントが発生し、選択肢を選ぶ）
2. 物資を得るために目的地の選択
（危険な大型マーケットに向かうのか、ガンショップに向かうのか。それとも探索せずにとにかくカナダへ向かうのか？）
3. 探索パート。マップをキャラを動かしゾンビを倒して探索。油断すると殺されるぞ！
4. SIEGE（ゾンビによる襲撃） 逃げることはできず、指定時間生き残って脱出

大まかにこの１～３を繰り返しながら定期的に４のゾンビ襲撃を生き残りつつカナダにむけて走り続けます。

車は燃料を消費するため、定期的に補充しなければ歩いて移動になってしまう。
食料も確保しなければメンバーの士気が下がり離反や裏切りがおこることも。
医薬品が無ければ怪我したメンバーを治療できずにジリ貧に。
弾薬がなければSIEGEで生き残るのが難しくなる。
イベントによってはバンディットの襲撃で仲間が負傷したり、ときには死亡したり。
逆に家に取り残された人を助けて、仲間として誘って旅の仲間を増やしたり。
物資に余裕があるならあえて補充せず進むのも手だったりと色々悩みながら進んでいきましょう。

やけにノリの良いBGMや、どこかで見た（リンクやブルース・リーなど）ようなキャラクターとの出会い
犬が銃器で大暴れしたり、車を投げて戦ったりとシリアスなノリではないのも遊びやすさにつながっています。

全編英語ですが、難しいことは書いてないので大丈夫。ぜひお試しください。

36186484.review:
TL:DR - Fun with brilliant reply value thanks to randomly generated scenario's/characters.

I had the perfect party:  Danial, my randomly generated starter with tons of ammo, a lassie with a sphere to keep zombies at bay, an other guy who recently joined that I also gave guns/ammo to, and Alvis. A martial artist who sings after he attacks and he wore a wolf mask.

The final siege started and I was ready to rock. I played through DRTC multiple times and I never got this far and I knew my party was more than capable. I entered a building and found 2 grenades. I picked them up and either I pressed the wrong button or someone in my party used it. To my horror, a grenade was thrown in our faces and it all happened in a flash. Danial was blown out the building and he had that skull mark above him while 2 of my other members died inside. My heart sank.

Alvis, had low HP from the blast and survived but at this point I didn't care because there was no way I would survive the last siege with one guy at low HP and no guns.

Miraculously, I managed to weave between zombies using martial arts on any lone ones in the way. I swear if Alvis had stood for a second longer near the Zombies at the border he would have died but alas, he didn't. I made it to Canada!

The fall and rise of emotions that whole scene gave me was a blast.

PROS: 

.No game plays out the same, so many different things can happen with the RNG

.Funny and light-hearted, not an edgy Zombie game does not take itself seriously.

.The music is good and wacky, it fits the tone of the game surprisingly well

.Just when you think you saw all the game has to offer, you have not.

.That feeling when you get good rng: AKA, finding a room with loads of food/ammo

.Every door you have not yet opened is marked with a small flash - Very Helpful!

.Risk for Reward gameplay - its getting dark, the music has turned ominous, the zombies are now faster. Do I enter this last building for more supplies or run back to the car?

.I have never felt too O.P. A lot of Zombie games make you a one man army near the end, but
DRTC can turn the tables on your supplies with random events

CONS:

.Gets addictive, losing in the game can be frustrating and makes you go"Just one more time" 

.When the game gives you bad rng. (Group members arguing over a fart, etc) Be warned, this 
game is a Troll but its the rng that makes it so interesting. 

.Its hard to make out your characters in hordes of zombies.

.Sometimes you will be doomed by the hordes and you just have to accept it.

Overall, I totally recommend DRTC. It surprised me by how good it was because I normally don't like Zombie games yet this is the best zombie game I have ever played.
(Resident Evil 4 does not count, they are not Zombies)

To this day, I still don't know who tossed that Grenade.

36157240.review:
Este juego.. Este p**o juego!

Esta genial!  

El camino de la muerte hacia Canada es un juego de administracion de recursos y decisiones de eventos, reclutaje y entrenamiento para llevar a tu pequeño grupo de sobrevivientes desde Florida hasta Canada y el final.. esta... GENIAL!

Primero que nada, el juego esta suficientemente dificil para no ser aburrido o frustrante. Me tarde dos dias para aprender a usar apropiadamente bombas y escopetas para llegar a Canada, creo que perdi como 16 veces antes de que al fin entendi como sobrevivir esos cuatro minutos de infierno Zombi y que no muriera de hambre a cada rato.

Aparte de eso, una vez que ya tienes una maestria en sobrevivencia en el modo "Normal" ahora tienes 8 modos mas para divertirte! Desde un modo maraton en donde tienes que jugar hasta la muerte hasta un modo donde solo salen puros personajes de chiste pero OP como Gigaman(megaman), Lunk (Link de Zelda), Rack Rhymes (The Walking Dead) y un monton mas que cuando los encuentras solo puedes sonreir con las tontadas que hacen.

Una corrida normal de 15 dias, desde principio a fin, dura mas o menos de 3 a 4 horas, creo, si es que te detienes a cada lugar que encuentras (y deberias), pero hay tantos personajes diferentes y lugares que explorar, que ya llevo una semana y aun encuentro cosas nuevas.

Ademas, el juego cuenta con un sistema de creacion de personaje con mas de 20 beneficios diferentes y otras 30 personalidades con la cual puedes hacer decenas de personajes para que encuentres tu propio estilo de supervivencia.
Tal vez te gusta andar de pistolero o levantador de muebles para aventarzelos a las hordas. SWOLE!

Adicionalmente, este juego es perfecto para jugarlo desde el sofa con un control para PC y hasta se puede jugar de dos jugadores en local en una sola PC.

Los logros son dificiles de sacar, hay logros que son mucho de suerte (que te salga un evento o personaje) y otros de habilidad (acabar el juego sin que te muerdan o que te maten) Yo diria que la dificultad esta en un 8 de 10, ya que hay muy pocos jugadores que tienen estos logros.

Este juego se merece 9 figuritas de Anime de 10 bombas molotov. Un tesoro de juego! <3

36036711.review:
この手のローグライクゲーでは珍しく最高難度をクリアするぐらいハマれたのでレビュー。
わずかな物資をオンボロ車に詰め込んで、安寧の地カナダを目指しバンディットとゾンビが蔓延る死の道を進むゲームタイトルそのままの内容です。

ゲームの基本的に流れとして、まず最初に初期メンバーを最大2人まで作成します。
ランダムで初めてもよし、自分でPerkやTraitを設定して作りそれらを使用する形でも可能です。
その後ゲームパートに入り
・探索先を選択して物資を探す（アクションパート）
・ランダムイベントで行動を選択
・トレーダーのキャンプ地で物資や武器の交換
この三つが道中にランダムで起こり、それらを上手く乗り越えながらカナダを目指します。
これ以外にもゾンビが襲ってきて一定時間耐えるアクションパートなどもあります。
ゲームモードは複数ありますが、カナダへの距離が変わったりゾンビが増えたりなどの変化だけでこの大まかな流れは変わりません。
全滅したら最初からですが、一定距離進む事に手に入るゾンビポイント(ZP)を使用してPerkやTraitのアンロックや強化ができたり、レア探索地やレアトレーダーの出現確率の上昇など恒久的に効果がある物のアンロックも可能です。


■面白かった点
・ドット絵とノリのいい音楽で終始楽しくプレイできる。
・設定できるPerkやTraitの数が多く色んなキャラが作れる。
・アクション操作が割と素直でストレスがなく強い武器を手に入れると爽快感がある。
・かといって終盤はゾンビの数が多いので徐々に追い詰められていく緊張感もある。
・どこかで見たことがあるレアキャラクター達が多い。
・なのでノーマルモードよりもレアキャラクターが多く出現するモードの方が面白い。
・アクションなので引きが悪くてもなんとか乗り切れることがある(逆パターンもあり)
・ZPを稼いでアンロックしていく楽しさ。

■イマイチだった点
・オフラインcoopのみ。
・全編英語なのでイベントで選択する際は多少意味を理解する必要がある(時間は止まるので調べることは可能)
・ゲームモードを変えても劇的にプレイ内容が変わる訳ではない。
・味方への指示が大雑把でしか出来ない。
・チェーンソーや火炎放射器など燃料を使う武器が強すぎてこれだけで乗り切れてしまう事が多い。


不満な点も書きましたがとても面白く、こういうゲームが好きな方にはお勧めです。


以下は自分がプレイした中でよく使っていたPerkとTraitをまとめたものです。
中にはZPでアンロックが必要な物もあります。

・脳筋近接キャラ
Perk-Athlete
Trait-Warrior
とりあえず自分がメインで操作するキャラ。
近接に必要なFitnessとStrengthが両方上がるので序盤が楽に。

・戦闘以外を全て任せるキャラ
Perk-HealthCare
Trait-Civilized
戦闘はからっきしだがその他を任せられるキャラ。
治療が出来て機転が効いて交渉も出来て冷静で人当たりがよくなり機械修理がそこそこできる。
イベントで問題が起きたら大体任せられるけど、ペナルティとして士気の最大値が低くなるのが難点。

・よりよい探索をするためのキャラ
Perk-Explorer
Trait-CitySeeker
とりあえず作ってみたけど最初の2キャラで安定しちゃうからいつも使えてないキャラ。
カスタムキャラとして作っておけば道中に出てくるから見つけたら雇ってる。
Explorerで探索地の選択肢が増えるのは便利。

35932457.review:
To the developers: 
Such a great "couch" co-op game. Just recently tried this game with my Nintendo Switch Joy Cons with my mom and boy do they feel just right for this game. Switch version through Nindies when? I'd gladly buy this game a second time. Not even kidding. The sooner this gets there the more sales it'll get before the other indies overflood the eShop, trust me.

To everyone else looking to buy this game: 
Highly recommended, if you're looking for a Halloween game that isn't all spooks and jumpscares but laughs and frustration (the good, entertaining kind) with a friend or family member, then this game is totally for you.

Death Road to Canada is a rougelike game, meaning it's maps and encounters are all randomized and when you die, you die for good and have to start over. But you unlock things the more you play, so dying isn't bad... Unless you die right away if you have terrible luck.

You can make your own characters and let them "inhabit" the world of Death Road to Canada and have a chance of meeting or even recruiting them as you play the game or choose a mode where you only meet the rare characters; each being super risky but super fun to have in a run.

The game has a ton of references to other games, lots of jokes and is overall hard not to enjoy or crack a smile at while playing it. It gets even better if you play it with a friend or family member. Some might not enjoy its humor, but I certainly do!

The music is also pretty good and I really dig its pixel art style.

One thing I have to mention, though, is that this game is probably not made for super long sessions solo. I think 30 minutes/until you die per day is more than enough, because otherwise you might get tired of this game fast. Personally I only play it when I can convince my 63 y/o mom to play it with me (I'm a 24 y/o loser with no friends and social anxiety, don't judge me too hard) and I get bored of it on my own after 30 minutes. 
This game is entertaining solo, too, but not as much as when you play co-op, in my opinion. If you expect a similar experience like Binding of Isaac or Enter the Gungeon, then I'll have to disappoint you.

All in all, though, I'd say this game is great if you need a co-op game for Halloween that's fun. I don't think online co-op is a thing yet, but I hope it will be.

35911766.review:
Who wouldn't want to go to Canada to escape the zombie-ocalypse?!

Death Road to Canada is a rogue like beat-um up with a fairly healthy dose of Oregon Trail like survival elements. 

Although you do have a great deal of control in the game, between what locations you scavenge, what choices you make (like whether to say give up supplies or ram a barricade set up by bandits), whether to sleep and rest or push on through.... 

The outcome will usually leave you guessing, or well... suffering. Even when you think you are making the best deicion, just like life, things don't always go the way you would hope. Your friend may stab you in the back and your forced to leave him behind cause morale is low. Or you may struggle through a horde due to injuries from a previous encounter. 

Every time you play it will feel like a whole new narrative is unfolding. There's even a surprising degree of customization too. You could choose a randomly generated character... or create your own set of familiar faces to use in the game. Give them personalities, and perk traits and see how far you can get with them. 

There's a lot to love with the games charming and odd humor, it's appealing pixelated visual style, and it's all over the place music (well that one is both love and hate.... sometimes the music doesn't really fit the mood, but you take the bad with the good). 

In the end it's a game worth picking up, and sure to give a solid amount of replay value to retro game loving zombie fanatics. Or anyone who just like to laugh their ass off at how it all plays out.

35840739.review: It's almost been a year since I've purchased Death Road to Canada, and I must say that even after all this time the game still holds up as incredible. The sheer concept of the game is brilliant, and the built in upgrade system for better future runs as well as laugh-out-loud dialog makes this game a must buy. It's so easy to start up and then pick up the game whenever, as the saving system allows you to complete one event at a time if need be, or complete an entire fun yet challenging run to Canada in one sitting. The game isn't easy, but that's where the bulk of the fun is with the game. Trying to figure out what character combinations go well together to ensure a good run is crucial, but if you want even more of a challenge you can attempt the Death Road solo, or better yet a BERSERK! solo run, which I plan on attempting in the future. Speaking of characters, the built in custom character creator is an outstanding feature of the game. Make your family, friends, favorite YouTubers, or even celebrities, give them their own perks and traits, and then upgrade them through Zombo Town. It makes the game feel especially satisfying when you and your brother make it to Canada, and when your custom character dies to a zombie it makes it even more heart-wrenching. Overall, I can't help but recommend Death Road to Canada for anyone who's considering purchasing the game. It has a ton of replayability, and is really cool to think a four person team made such an incredible title. Can't wait to buy it again once the Android verison releases the 26th! 10/10

35650790.review: Death Road to Canada revolves around you, a completely customizable character, trying to survive against hordes of zombies on the way to Canada, as is implied. This game is very strong in its performance as a fun family game, being that it is a two player offline game, which is a gem in the online dominating market. The dialogue is witty, the art is undeniably creative and masterful, the characters can be made to whomever you want, and the gameplay gets tense in your plight to live. While the game is very short, it is hard to beat, and is very good in its replayability, unlike many other offline games, giving it yet another edge. This game is a rare gem in the era of games that are in the market now, and it can be savored for hours on end.

35626199.review:
I first found out about Death Road to Canada when I watched a friend stream it. I had a great time watching and decided to get it myself. 57+ hours of gameplay later, I know that it was definitely well worth the purchase.

The best part of Death Road to me is that each run is a new adventure. Events and choices are randomly given for you to make, many of which throw in some great humor. In one run, you could end up having to fight your way to a UFO that you can somehow drive, and in another, you might have to use your trusty shotgun or chainsaw to reach the end of a sewer. There's many different things and places to discover and enjoy.

Death Road also strongly delivers in its gameplay. It might look easy enough in the trailers to fight through zombies, but when you play the game, it's engaging and offers a unique challenge. You have to manage your resources wisely from the beginning of the run to (hopefully) the end, and you've gotta use your best skills wisely, like your shooting and strength. It might seem like a lot at first, but once you get the basics down, it's really entertaining.

Piece of advice: Don't expect yourself to win the first time you play. In order to have a winning run, you've gotta practice your techniques and how to manage your resources. However, with each run being unique and the gameplay being as engaging as it is, getting better and better is nowhere near boring. Each run builds confidence, and you find yourself strongly looking forward to the day you finally cross that border. Once you win the first time, more modes are unlocked, each of which provides a new challenge for you to face.

One last thing that I want to briefly mention is the ending to a successful run. I won't spoil what it is, but I'll just say that it's greatly rewarding after all the hours that you put into the game. When I won for the first time, the ending made it greatly satisfying, especially since I never used a wiki along the way.

This is a remarkable game, and I definitely recommend getting it. It's often on sale for 10 dollars, but if you're impatient like me and pay the full 15, you're still getting quite a bang for your buck.

35559613.review:
Death Road to Canada: the name explains it all. It's an indie RPG where you, well, travel the Death Road up into Canada. What's a death road? Think a highway full of zombies. 'Nuff said.
       The way I like to think of it, Death Road is a roguelike that offers some satisfying gameplay. it is an RPG that allows you to create your characters. Design their appearance, name them and decide their personality. This is a very fun mechanic, as it allows you to shape the story of your adventure. Combat is fun as well. You are able to freely switch between your party of four, while having three weapons equipped. Your characters have stamina, and guns have ammo. it is simple, but it is resourceful and effective.
        That's another thing to keep in mind: resources. This actually is extremely important: this can either ruin you or save your butt in clutch moments. it is easy to learn management(its kind of auto). Since these are randomly generated, you won't know what to expect to happen next each time you start your new game. Lastly, as one tip to n00bs: DO NOT buy any anime less you fancy starving to death. You'll see what I mean.
        Graphically, the game excels. As I said in my UnderTale review, the graphics here also carry that "delicious" look to them. This, in conjunction with the music, creates some darn well effective atmosphere. I should elaborate on the music": its great. The tracks perfectly emphasize the mood of the game: one minute, you're like a bawss; the next, you're depessed as heck. On their own, though, the ost is still top tier.
        One last thing I should mention that unfortunately makes or breaks this game: the game is a troll. I am serious. The game itself is a troll. This, of course, leads to hysterical moments, but it can get old after a while. And when I mean get old, I mean OLD. Eventually, you'll get sick of hearing that your characters die after stubbing their toe. Events like these happen all the time. I can see how casuals would flee from this game thanks to its often unforgiving difficulty, where every mistake has a brutal consequence. What can be a very enjoyable aspect of the game is unfortunately also its hubris.
         Overall, Death Road to Canada is yet another fantastic RPG on Steam. With satisfying gameplay, good visuals and music, and a successful take at the zombie genre, it is a fun experience all around. Though the game's trollish side can alienate the player, one perseverant enough can deal with this issue and appreciate the humor behind it. 
My Score: 8.5/10(Great)

35558307.review:
Death Road To Canada is a fun and very funny rogue-lite that is well worth the price. 

Most of the game will be spent scavanging, moving around the map killing zombies and taking any supply that isnt nailed down. The gameplay for these areas is simple but effective beat em up style with guns when you can get enough bullets. One zombie will not hassle you too much but get caught in a group of them and you will be taking damage. You can have up to four charecters in your team and the AI is halfway decent when it comes to grabbing supplies and weapons that you might have missed. 

In between areas you will travel in the car. Occasionally special events with mutiple choice outcomes will present themselves and this is where the games humor and quirkeyness really shine. The writing has a lot of charm to it and the game never takes itself too seriously. 

I would definetly recommend Death Road To Canada if you are a fan of rogue-lite style games.

Well, I've caught the roguelike/te bug again with this game... After playing Death Skid Marks, Binding of Isaac, Enter the Gungeon, FTL, Monolith, Nuclear Throne, and Risk of Rain to death, I'm really glad to have found this game. It's deceptively cute - the 2d graphics and goofy writing hide a punishing and rewarding experience. There are a zillion unique (recruitable and non-recruitable) characters that all have their own events, and coming across them can change the tide of your run... or maybe the special character you just paid 12 food to recruit is actually a crappy waste of space. 
Much like every other roguelike/te out there, you'll play for about two hours before feeling comfortable with your starting build; when you find a great main/buddy character synergy, it's rewarding as hell! Oh, and couch co-op is a lot of fun.

Enjoy this game, get mad at this game, and play it just one more time before bed. Just one more time. Ok, one more time for real.

35400361.review:
This game seems fun at first, but it's filled with extremely frustrating RNG mechanics. You can literally have everything great, going your way and then with the turn of the next RNG event you're now doing horribly. Most fun games with these mechanics make it hard to get what you need, but if you get what's required you're usually ok unless you take dumb risks. Even playing it safe, you will get screwed by this game.

I've done at least a dozen plus runs now, gotten to the last day and had multiple rare characters in my party with good loadouts and supplies, but even with a four man party it's not fun and was not possible to win. I'm sure if you waste enough hours playing the game you'll get the lucky specific combo needed to win, but it rapidly becomes unfun. You'll lose your car very easily and the game does everything possible to throw horrible events at you when this inevitability happens.

Not recommended, it's just too frustrating to play and not rewarding enough on playthroughs that it either feels better on successive runs or fun enough to grind through.

35284715.review:
This is a zombie survival road trip simulator full of dad jokes.

In Death Road To Canada, your goal is to survive a trip from Florida to Canada, acquiring cars, looting ruins, and running from a truly monstrous amount of zombies.  Up to four people can fit in the cars you find - and a bevy of strange special encounters make each run unique.

The humor is the weirdest and best part of the game.  Each game has a bit of a "you had to be there" element to it which makes it hard to explain (I just survived an encounter by having a circus clown sign up for a pose-off with bandits), but since each game has so many weird traits, learning these encounters and mastering the weirdness for yourself is a huge part of the fun.

There are some qualms - the controls occasionally stick, and the language isn't quite well translated - but if you want an over-the-top serial-encounter game to scratch the itch that Super Amazing Wagon Adventure left, this is one road trip you'll want to take.

35145087.review:
The graphics are good at what it needs to do. If you enjoy pixel art and 2D games, go for it. It's not a masterpiece in the art-style but it does the job and is enjoyable.

Customizing your own characters with traits and perks is pushing the immersion on a personal side which is great.
You can pretty much create any kind of characters with all the personality traits, perks and customizations available.
I created two characters that looks like friends of mine,  a buffed Roady and berserked D-Bag, a Ninja-like character and, well, myself in two different ways. That's neat. Could create a lot more and it's fun to try and deal with all these different possibilities of personalities. 

The gameplay is divided in two segment, on the road and on foot.
On the road, you'll be given choices to deal with and locations to choose from in text format while seeing your car rolling or your character(s) running on the road in the background.
On foot, you can control your characters using the weapons available that you've collected, smashing through hoards of zombies to find loot you'll need to continue your journey. The hitboxes are alright and the way you don't get hurt on contact is a lot of fun to deal with... when you're not swarmed and where it's impossible to escape
But hey! Sh*t happens! The name of the game is there for a reason.

The story is always the same but it's the adventure that counts the most, stuff that is happening on the road, a character you cherished just died in front of your eyes, recruting random characters or ones that you customized yourself, like if you're finding an old friend.

The music is alright but not that memorable other than the main title theme.
It can get kind of repetitive in the long run but it's not that annoying either.

In overall, It's a lot of fun!

If you're already into indie titles, pixel art and such, I do recommend it.
If you're not into these kind of games, you know what to do. Keep on rolling!

RESUMEN:
Death Road to Canada nos presenta un divertido juego con partes de "rol" y gestion de recursos (montados en el coche) y slasheo del bueno hacia los zombies. Nuestro destino ? Llegar a Canada como sea posible, Sientate en el sofa con parejas y/o amig@s y a disfrutar a lo grande de esta aventura. Sobrevive, el juego te obligara tanto a tomar decisiones que pueden jo""""e el viaje a Canada, como a demostrar tu destreza ante oleadas  de zombies, solo para conseguir una latita de comida, por la que luego os peleareis tus colegas y tu. LO DEMAS:
Creo que este juego en si, es un puntazo. Una de las cosas que mas señalaria son las habilidades, cada jugador consta de 3 "naturalezas" innatas a elegir, que constan de un pro o un contra, estas ayudaran en la evolucion del personaje. La divertida personalizacion del personaje, las situaciones por las que pasan, los momentos de supervivencia y de rol, las armas ridiculas e improvisadas (como lanzar carritos), el pixelart cuidado, LA SORPRESA FINAL MUY GRANDE JAJAJA.
Gran cantidad de personajes ridiculamente fantasticos, personaliza a tu propio personaje, crea a tus amigos ( o que jueguen contigo) y se su heroe salvador o expulsalos del coche, quedate sin gasolina y ve a patas, ENSEÑA A UN PERRO A COGER UNA ESCOPETA O CONDUCIR JAJAJAJA, puntazos!. 34764068.review:
Yeah, it's alright. Why? Well...

The game is a large and very comical zombie road trip simulator that almost never takes itself too seriously. It's like Organ Trail if the point was to get to Canada instead of Oregon and you deal with everyone being a jerk while fighting through an endless flood of zombies. You try your best to go from the bottom of Florida to Canada while scavanging food, fuel, and weapons to survive until then. So, yeah, same old stuff.

But...

There's a lot more that seperates DRTC from the overwhelming majority of zombie survival simulations (excluding Organ Trail). For one, it's a rougue-like, which means it's so hard that you are almost never going to beat this game unless you are blessed with the luckiest Irish blood in all of the world (or just lucky). It's also filled with an ENOURMOUS plethora of weapons, road scenarioes, and various characters, including characters from games and movies, to generic pop culture people, several animals, the infinite random generator, and any more you create yourself. There's a great selection of comedic situations and dialogue options that may at least give you a few genuine laughs. Plus, since that huge anniversary update, there's almost no bugs and plenty more stuff in general to enjoy.

However, this game may frustrate you or leave you without any smiles, depending on your opinion of these types of games. So, if you don't enjoy humor along the lines of the following scenario, then you have been warned.

"Your group has been ambushed by a group of bandits who're asking for all of your stuff or else they're gonna beat you up. How do you respond?"

A. Fred knew this was coming - "Fred, since he's paranoid, saw this a mile away. While everyone else went on ahead, he came around in the car for a double ambush! The bandits are so surprised, that they run off while you drive away."

B. Dave tells them to 'COOL IT!' - "Because telling someone to 'cool it' has never worked in the history of ever, the bandits become so enraged that they begin to beat up Dave mercilessly. Since he was already injured, Dave dies. The bandits, preoccupied, ignore the rest of your group as they drive away."

C. The Last Bodybuilder challenges them to a POSE OFF! - "The leader of the bandits, a large and burly guy, steps up. The Last Bodybuilder was hardly able to break a sweat as the bandit leader slinks off in shame and lets you guys through."

**I am not quoting this exactly, I am guessing from memory!!!**

Besides that, my final verdict is this: it's a great game that has a childish and endearing sense of humor, a well designed character roster, and many great qualities that make it quite fun if you don't try to play to win. So, yeah, it's alright, and as long as you have a similar sense of humor, then it should make for a fun few weekends' worth of good times.

7/10, It's alright.

34745934.review:
This game is just tons of fun to play, especially with a friend. Just finished making it to Canada my first time and the feeling of accomplishment and success were very much at the forefront of my mind upon crossing the border. At times the game can be downright hilarious with moments of funny and bizarre comedy spread throughout the loose, emergent narrative. There are multiple narrative junctions in which you must make decisions and choose certain outcomes for various members of your party. Depending upon group composition this can lead to some surprising, funny or downright terrible outcomes depending on your luck. 

The game is surprisingly slow at times giving the player time to plan and talk amongst friends or themselves adding an enjoyable layer of strategy and depth to what would be a mindless top down shooter otherwise. DRtC also features an intuitive and integral item scavening system in place that adds constant tension throughout as you juggle between items/weapons on you at any given moment. 
You must constantly be aware of your supplies. Food, gas, meds, etc. all share the same pool for the party and must be balanced and incessantly managed, especially on the harder/ longer game modes. DRtC's art style is colorful and detailed with most character models being distinct and very stylistic, especially those that are more hidden or of the easter-egg variety. The game also boasts a rockin, chip-tune soundtrack that makes your zombie slaying that much more enjoyable. 

Overall, I had more fun than I ever expected and plan to play more, hopefully with friends again. My only complaints are the lack of enemy types; different kinds of zombies/infected would have been an added bonus. Also, the lack of an online functionality is surprising as I don't always have access to a friend sitting next to me to play... at least not nowadays. Hopefully this is something the devs will add in the future perhaps.

Regardless, for 15 bucks it's worth the cash. You've got multiple hours of laughs, thrills, and  numerous means of replayability all awaiting you on your  wild trip to the Canadian border. Do yourself (and your friends) a favor and grab this one if you're on the fence about it.

34723551.review:
Ok, this is my first review on steam, so don't expect much

Death Road to Canada is one of the best games I have ever played on steam. It has comedy (get irritating perk and spam usage), epic zombie splatting with a pretty big variety on weapons, skills that make keeping survivors alive very recommended, a huge variety of locations (along with rare locations with special loot/effects), 2 player local co-op, and 10 gamemodes to put it in a summary. A potato can run this game, and a potato can win this game. I honestly do not see the trouble people have, because the game only becomes borderline impossible by the last 4 gamemodes. Anyhow, the only reason to not buy the game is there is no online multiplayer. Besides that, 10/10 would get eaten alive again because I forgot to bring my chainsaw. If you go into the game though, a few pieces of advice:

1. Set up custom characters, probably 1 to two dozen. They are MUCH better than random characters. This helps a lot with getting a balanced team!

2. Don't forget your unlocks on the main screen! This becomes very important because you spend points for beating events on the long road to get better perks and traits

3. Only take as many people/guns as you need! The more people you recruit, the more food you need, the less weapons/ammo you can buy at traders, and the more guns you bring to sieges/looting events, the less ammo you have, only use it when you need it or you will run out!

4. You have to learn the basics of where good looting and bad looting are ingame, so try and try again! Be aware of how you are losing so you don't do the same thing over and over again

5. Actually worry about skills! And I'd advise bringing a very strong/fit buddy with you.

34402904.review: This game is too good. The gameplay is simple yet effective at presenting an adequate challenge later in your runs, the rng road events are interesting and so numerous that if you keep playing you'll probably find something you've never seen! The first time I played I got two days away from Canada, when I lost I wanted to be angry, I wanted to feel like I was cheated, but the game was simply too charming for me to act like like that and made me keep playing for two more rounds until I won. Multiple Gamemodes, Character Customization, Randomly Generated "Always Be Looting" Areas, and Hilarious and Zany Text-Based Events make this game one of the most replayable games that is definitely worth the price of admission. I could keep praising this game for another few paragraphs, but instead I'm just going to say this: This game is an emotional rollercoaster that has left me with tears in my eyes, my sides split, my life affected, my eyes gleaming, and my heart touched. AND THEY'RE STILL UPDATING ALL OF WHAT I'VE SAID PREVIOUSLY!
